memprof 0.0.1
  • Get started
  • Reference

    memprof

    memprof.Rmd
    library(memprof)

    Memory profiling

    memprof will evaluate an R expression whilst monitoring the processes memory and memory of any child process over time.

    Create you have a function you want to monitor the memory for e.g.

    f <- function(msg) {
  Sys.sleep(1)
  z <- numeric(1e8) ## 800MB
  Sys.sleep(1)
  msg
}

    Profile it using memprof

    memprof <- with_monitor(f("hello"))

    This will return an object with the result memprof$result and the profiling data memprof$memory_use. The memory_use data collected will depend on the OS used, see ?ps::ps_memory_info for more details.

    head(memprof$memory_use)
#>         time   id parent_id name       rss       vms   shared text lib
#> 1 0.02685332 6804      6611    R 108302336 443707392 27893760 4096   0
#> 2 0.13708138 6804      6611    R 108302336 443707392 27893760 4096   0
#> 3 0.24741435 6804      6611    R 108302336 443707392 27893760 4096   0
#> 4 0.36306906 6804      6611    R 108302336 443707392 27893760 4096   0
#> 5 0.47190404 6804      6611    R 108302336 443707392 27893760 4096   0
#> 6 0.58105874 6804      6611    R 108302336 443707392 27893760 4096   0
#>        data dirty
#> 1 320151552     0
#> 2 320151552     0
#> 3 320151552     0
#> 4 320151552     0
#> 5 320151552     0
#> 6 320151552     0

    The profile can be plotted

    plot(memprof)

    Expressions which spawn child processes

    If your expression spawns any other processes, these will be included in the monitor output too, consider

    g <- function() {
  
  f <- function(msg) {
    Sys.sleep(1)
    z <- numeric(1e8) ## 800MB
    Sys.sleep(1)
    msg
  }
  
  p <- callr::r_bg(f, list(msg = "hello from f"))
  p$wait()
  c("hello from g", p$get_result())
}

    Profile it using memprof

    memprof <- with_monitor(g())

    Note the memory use data will contain two ids

    unique(memprof$memory_use$id)
#> [1] 6804 6854

    The profile can be plotted, this will sum the memory for all the processes at each time point

    plot(memprof)

    Profile total system memory

    You can also profile total system memory by using

    memprof <- with_monitor(f("hello"), mode = "system")

    This will return an object with the result memprof$result and the profiling data memprof$memory_use. The memory_use data collected will depend on the OS used, see ?ps::ps_system_memory for more details.

    head(memprof$memory_use)
#>          time      total      avail  percent      used       free    active
#> 1 0.009918213 7281274880 6094315520 16.30153 853356544 2896711680 939388928
#> 2 0.111534357 7281274880 6093611008 16.31121 854061056 2895994880 939393024
#> 3 0.213096380 7281274880 6093361152 16.31464 854310912 2895736832 939401216
#> 4 0.314790964 7281274880 6093103104 16.31818 854568960 2895478784 939401216
#> 5 0.416483879 7281274880 6092845056 16.32173 854827008 2895220736 939401216
#> 6 0.518216848 7281274880 6092587008 16.32527 855085056 2894962688 939401216
#>     inactive   buffers     cached  shared      slab
#> 1 2720354304 304394240 3226812416 7368704 574873600
#> 2 2720669696 304394240 3226824704 7368704 574906368
#> 3 2720903168 304402432 3226824704 7368704 574840832
#> 4 2721087488 304402432 3226824704 7368704 574840832
#> 5 2721325056 304402432 3226824704 7368704 574840832
#> 6 2721562624 304402432 3226824704 7368704 574840832

    The profile can be plotted

    plot(memprof)

    Profile a process which errors

    You can specify the file to write the memory usage logs to. You can use this to log memory usage of the system in a way which can be recovered if the expression you are evaluating might fail.

    f <- function(msg) {
  Sys.sleep(1)
  z <- numeric(1e8) ## 800MB
  Sys.sleep(1)
  stop("An error")
  msg
}

monitor_file <- tempfile()
tryCatch(with_monitor(f(), monitor_file = monitor_file),
         error = function(e) e)
#> <simpleError in f(): An error>
memory_use <- monitor_read(monitor_file)

plot(memory_use)
